head.title: QUICK BITE/North Plainfield; Fat Boy in a Red Tower

identified-content.org: Red Tower Ii (North Plainfield, Nj, Restaurant)

hedline.hl1: QUICK BITE/North Plainfield; Fat Boy in a Red Tower

abstract.p: Jack Silbert reviews Red Tower II restaurant in North Plainfield, NJ; drawing (M)

block.p: In 1911, the French painter Robert Delaunay returned to his favorite subject, the Eiffel Tower, and created an intriguing work called ''The Red Tower.'' In 1936, Plainfield residents anticipated my favorite subject -- the hamburger -- and created an intriguing restaurant, also called the Red Tower. Both creations proved admirable and influential. Yet only one is historically linked with Fat Boy hamburgers.

Flash forward to the year 2000: it was then that I visited Red Tower's sister restaurant, Red Tower II, on Route 22 in North Plainfield. Sure, I was curious about the original joint. I've even heard it sports a red turret. But this is a Quick Bite, and for these, I stick to the highways.

In 1911, the French painter Robert Delaunay returned to his favorite subject, the Eiffel Tower, and created an intriguing work called ''The Red Tower.'' In 1936, Plainfield residents anticipated my favorite subject -- the hamburger -- and created an intriguing restaurant, also called the Red Tower. Both creations proved admirable and influential. Yet only one is historically linked with Fat Boy hamburgers.

Flash forward to the year 2000: it was then that I visited Red Tower's sister restaurant, Red Tower II, on Route 22 in North Plainfield. Sure, I was curious about the original joint. I've even heard it sports a red turret. But this is a Quick Bite, and for these, I stick to the highways.

Questions swirled in my head: Was Red Tower a local response to the old White Tower chain (itself a White Castle knockoff)? And what on earth is a Fat Boy hamburger? Entering Red Tower II, you are greeted by the cartoon image of a fat boy. A distant cousin of Bob's Big Boy? A hasty Internet search revealed ''Fat Boy'' burgers on the menu of a few scattered, seemingly unrelated establishments across America, but gave little insight on where Fat Boy fits in our hamburger heritage?

Red Tower II offers up aselection of for breakfast, lunch and dinner, at reasonable (yet oddly unrounded) prices. I selected the quarter-pound Fat Boy with cheese ($2.97) and large fries ($1.98). I appreciated the Fat Boy's fresh ground beef, though the patty got a little lost in the over-sized Kaiser roll.

The d'ecor is wood-grain Formica as far as the eye can see. Tiffany-style hanging lamps provide atmosphere. They also provide light. Delaunay scholars may disagree, but I envision the artist's final days. He is relaxing in a cafe in Montpellier. Inspiration strikes. Reaching for a cocktail napkin, Delaunay tunes out the world, and sketches the Fat Boy.
Red Tower II, 864 Route 22, North Plainfield, (908) 754-0002. Red Tower, 500 Park Avenue, Plainfield, (908) 561-0353.
